body.p: Before we get into the details of how to use this product, a few sample use cases are described below to provide an idea of the types of problems that FogHorn systems can solve. In this user guide, we use the Winder Demo example to demonstrate the base capabilities of the product release.

topic.title: Winder Machine

body.p: In this real-world manufacturing scenario, FogHorn Lightning is used to monitor the condition of critical assets on the factory floor.

High-frequency transformers operating in the tens to hundreds of kilohertz often have windings made of large conducting sheets. These sheets need to be rolled with great precision. Winder machine is comprised of temperature, speed, roll width, sheet diameter, and winder tension sensors to monitor the condition of the winding in real time. These sensor inputs have certain characteristics, and any small variations can cause entire transformers to malfunction. The FogHorn Lightning system lets us monitor the data coming from these sensors in real time.

Using FogHorn Lightning, winder operators can see the analytics in real time with the VIZ app. Apart from basic analytics, the operator can also perform real-time machine learning with the edgeML app. Through edgeML, operators can perform complex analytics that enables them to find a "needle in the haystack."

topic.title: Store and Forward

body.p: We provide data integrity with FogHorn Lightning's Store and Forward feature. Imagine that there is a loss of network connection, so the destination is temporarily inaccessible. Lightning's data publisher immediately buffers the published data in the local file system. When the endpoint is reachable, all the stored data is forwarded seamlessly.
This feature prevents data loss from a sudden accident of the destination site. The whole process is transparent to the end-user.

topic.title: Add a Video Sensor to the Edge

body.p: Before you can upload and analyze videos with Video Agent, create a video sensor to ingest your MP4 video files.

note.p: Note: Before you add a video sensor to the edge, make sure you already set up a video server in FogHorn Manager.

ol.li: In FogHorn Manager, click the edge that you want to process video data.
In the edge details panel, click SENSORS | Add a Sensor.

Specify the following settings:
Setting Name Value
Name
The name of the video sensor.
Protocol server
Select a video server.
Sampling Period (sec)
The number of seconds between video frames that you want to analyze. For example, if you set the sampling period to 5, Video Agent selects a frame from the video every 5 seconds and writes those frames to the topic.
Publishing Interval (sec)
The number of seconds of delay between when the frame is collected and when it's written to the topic. For example, if you set the publishing interval to 10, Video Agent waits 10 seconds after it collects a video frame to write the frame to the topic.
Topic
The name for the sensor's topic. The data from this sensor is written to this topic.
Click SAVE | DEPLOY CONFIG.

note.p: Remember to issue the fh_util.sh mount command if /opt/fh is not mounted already.

li.p: Create a file called log4j.properties somewhere accessible to the application.
where app-name is something relevant to the application being debugged.
Create file logback.xml somewhere accessible to the application:
li.codeblock:
<configuration>
<appender name="FILE" class="ch.qos.logback.core.FileAppender"> <file>/opt/fh/logs/<app-name>.log</file>
<encoder> <pattern>%date %level [%thread] %logger{10} [%file:%line] %msg%n</pattern> </encoder> </appender>
<appender name="STDOUT" class="ch.qos.logback.core.ConsoleAppender"> <!– encoders are assigned the type ch.qos.logback.classic.encoder.PatternLayoutEncoder by default –> <encoder> <pattern>%d{HH:mm:ss.SSS} [%thread] %-5level %logger{36} – %msg%n</pattern> </encoder> </appender>
<root level="debug"> <appender-ref ref="FILE" /> <appender-ref ref="STDOUT" /> </root> </configuration>
log4j.appender.file.layout.ConversionPattern=%d{yyyy-MM-dd HH:mm:ss} [%t] %-5p %c{1}:%L – %m%n

body.codeblock: environment: – CAVITATION_MONITOR_OPTS=-Dlog4j.configuration=file: {absolute path to file} -Dlogback.configurationFile=file:<absolute-path>/logback.xml

topic.title: Understanding VIZ

body.p: With VIZ, you can create dashboards with several widgets, where each widget can be a chart, graph, gauge, or text viewer.

A dashboard lets you monitor several different data streams. For example, imagine monitoring temperature data streams on a fleet of trucks carrying food produce in freezers. A line graph can be used to track the temperature, whereas the map widget helps locate the vehicle position.
In this section, we walk through the features of VIZ and describe how to create a new dashboard, add charts, and edit them.

topic.title: Overview

body.p: REX (replay/extract) is a multipurpose tool that can be used for simulating sensor traffic and debugging issues in production and test IoT environments. The current version of the tool supports four major types of functionality:

li.p: Generate new traffic (Play)

ul.li: Generate random sensor data as integers and float in a specified range
Generate data in an incremental step manner based on a configurable step interval (e.g 1,2,3,4)
Create complex data generation recipes using serial and parallel mode
Support the simulation of sensors that support MQTT, OPCUA, Modbus, ZMQ protocols

li.p: Capture live traffic (Capture)

ul.li: Capture data directly from MQTT, OPCUA, Modbus, ZMQ brokers/servers
Capture live sensor data to a time series database (influxdb) for playback in the future

li.p: Extract data from a DB (Extract)

ul.li: Selectively extract previously captured data from the influxdb to a csv file
Ability to specify start, end, age of the data
Ability to limit extraction to specific topics (tables)

li.p: Replay data from file (Replay)

ul.li: Read data from a csv file and send data to specific topics
Ability to preserve timing information specified in the csv file
Ability to replay captured data at a slower or faster rate
Create complex recipes using serial and parallel mode
Support the simultation of sensors that support MQTT, OPCUA, Modbus, ZMQ protocols

li.p: REX doesn't support MQTT simulations that have a delay of 90 seconds or more.
REX supports simulations using RexUI for only one opcua sensor at a time. If there are multiple opcua sensors in one simulation, you must create multiple simulations. One for each opcua sensor.

ul.li: Only modbus TCP functionality is provided
REX will run in a slave mode and will respond with appropriate function codes in the messages based on the request. For example for a Read Coil request, REX will respond with a Read Coil response
Messages supported: Read Coil (FC=1), Read Discrete Inputs (FC=2), Read Holding Registers (FC=3), Read Input Registers (FC=4)
Write coil messages (FC=5,6,15) will be acknowledged in the slave mode

In Capture mode, REX will generate the request as specified in FC and retrieve 128 bytes of data starting from address 0. This should suffice for basic debugging to see if data in the registers (topic) is actually changing for each request.
REX uses unitid = 0 by default (i.e responds to all values of unit ids)

topic.title: Overview

body.p: REX (replay/extract) is a multipurpose tool that can be used for simulating sensor traffic and debugging issues in production and test IoT environments. REXUI is a UI for REX. The current version of REXUI supports three major types of functionality:

li.p: Generate new traffic

ul.li: Generate random sensor data as integers and float in a specified range
Generate data in an incremental step manner based on a configurable step interval (e.g 1,2,3,4)
Create complex data generation recipes using serial and parallel mode
Support the simulation of sensors that support MQTT and OPCUA protocols

li.p: Replay data from a csv file

ul.li: Read data from a csv file and send data to specific topics
Ability to replay data at a slower or faster rate
Create complex recipes using serial and parallel mode
Support the simulation of sensors that support MQTT and OPCUA protocols

li.p: Replay captured data

ul.li: Read and send data from a captured csv file to the topic specified in the file
Ability to preserve timing information specified in the captured csv file
Ability to replay captured data at a slower or faster rate
Create complex recipes using serial and parallel mode
Support the simulation of sensors that support MQTT and OPCUA protocols
NOTE: REXUI does not support the capture functionality. It can only replay previously captured data.

lq.p: Note: * REX doesn't support MQTT simulations that have a delay of 90 seconds or more. * REX supports simulations using RexUI for only one opcua sensor at a time. If there are multiple opcua sensors in one simulation, you must create multiple simulations. One for each opcua sensor.

topic.title: Protocol Agent

body.p: A protocol agent is a software component that runs on an edge device. The protocol agent gathers raw data, typically from protocol servers like MQTT, OPC-UA, or MODBUS, and publishes the data to the Lightning platform. For example, an OPC-UA Agent creates subscriptions to consume data from an OPC-UA server and publishes the data it receives to the Lightning platform.

topic.title: Data Encoding

body.p: Messages published to the Lightning platform are encoded in a wire format determined by the agent. For example, the OPC-UA Agent publishes data in OPC-UA binary format.

An MQTT-Agent, on the other hand, does not define an encoding itself. It assumes the encoding of the MQTT client publishing data to it. Data written to an MQTT-Agent could be either a UTF-8-encoded JSON string, or an ASCII-encoded string that contains key-value pairs.

topic.title: Decoder

body.p: To read data from the Lightning platform, the consumer must know its encoding, so it can parse fields and values. When ingesting data from a heterogeneous set of sensors, it is common to have numerous raw data encodings streaming on the Lightning platform. To increase the accessibility of this raw data, each raw data stream is forked into a raw encoding stream and a normalized encoding stream. If the target normalized encoding is in JSON, then all raw data is converted to JSON when it is ingested into Lightning. The decoder that's running on the Lightning platform implements the decode interface, which provides this transformation:

topic.title: Schema

body.p: The data flowing under different topics on the Lightning platform has different schemas, which allows developers to interact with and write applications to consume the data. The topics are analogous to database tables in traditional RDBMS products.

The schema describes the structure of the normalized encoding of the data. When using JSON as the normalized encoding, json-schema is used as the schema. The decoder service calls the function to get the desired schema based on the decoder plugin interface, which provides the transformation between the input, or raw topic, and the normalized encoding.
The raw topic metadata provides information about the structure of the encoded data. For example, for OPC-UA binary format, the following structure provides the raw topic metadata:

The OPC-UA built-in decoder uses this metadata to decode the binary data, which is an encoded structure that contains temperature and pressure fields. Given the metadata, the built-in OPC-UA decoder’s output schema function returns the following JSON schema:
The OPC-UA built-in decoder’s decode implementation returns JSON data.

topic.title: Problem Statement

body.p: The FogHorn Lightning platform comes with a set of built-in protocol agents and decoders that cover the most popular protocols in typical IoT environments. If the set of built-in agents does not provide the protocol support that you need, take advantage of Lightning Platform's extensibility model to implement your own protocol agent or decoder.

li.p: A customer uses custom encoding with an existing protocol. Example: MQTT client sending proprietary text format. The customer implements the decoder interface, and configures the protocol to use the custom encoding type. Metadata can be optionally provided at the topic level.

A customer uses a custom protocol to send data in a supported encoding. Example: Proprietary messaging protocol client sending utf-8 encoded key-value data. The customer implements a protocol agent, but configures the topics it publishes to using a built-in encoding and metadata.

A customer uses a custom protocol and custom encoding. Example: Proprietary messaging protocol client sending proprietary binary encoding. The customer implements a protocol agent and decoder and configures the protocol to use the custom encoding type.

topic.title: Implementing a Custom Protocol Agent

body.p: The protocol agent is a piece of software that runs on the edge device and writes raw data to the Lightning platform. The agent is not necessarily managed by FogHorn Lightning, although you can deploy the agent as a FogHorn Lightning application. The protocol agent developer can use the FogHorn SDK, which provides a client library for publishing data to the Lightning platform. You must define the topics to which the custom protocol agent publishes data. The FogHorn Lightning platform uses this topic definition to instantiate an appropriate decoder to normalize data as it is ingested.

return—JSON string specifying the schema of the decoded messages.

li.p: Required function that decodes the input message where:

If the custom decoder developer is using a C++ compiler to create the shared library, these functions should be wrapped inside a extern "C" directive, so the symbols associated with these functions load properly.

All the required dependencies other than standard C and C++ libraries must provided as part of the library. Another option is to provide dependent libraries using the LD_LIBRARY_PATH environment setting before starting the decoder service on the edge node.

topic.title: Winder Machine - Context

body.p: High-frequency transformers operating in the tens to hundreds of kilohertz often have windings made of large conducting sheets. These sheets need to be rolled with great precision. In order to ensure precision, winder machines use temperature, speed, roll width, sheet diameter, and winder tension sensors to monitor the condition of the winding in real time. These sensor inputs have certain characteristics, and small variations in the windings can cause entire transformers to malfunction.

FogHorn Lightning monitors and alerts operators when there is an anomaly in the real-time sensor streams. Winder operators can assess the state of their assets. Additionally, they can see live data streams with VIZ.

An operator can also perform real-time machine learning with Lightning's EdgeML application. EdgeML lets you execute machine learning models on the edge with live data. With EdgeML, operators perform complex analytics to identify issues.

Namespace Index: 2

Type: Double

topic.title: Analytics Expressions

li.p: Copy and paste the following VEL expression in the Expression window.
li.codeblock:
# DataTypes line_num is 3 winder_equip_str is "Winding" station_id is "Winding Line 6" opcua_bool is {value is bool} opcua_real is {value is real} rfid_type is {tagID is str, readerName is str} winder_data_type is { process is str, line is int, aspect_ratio is real, avg_line_speed is real, tension is real, avg_temp is real, serials is list(rfid_type) }
# Variables winder_diameter is stream("winder_diameter",opcua_real) winder_temperature is stream("winder_temperature",opcua_real) winder_speed is stream("winder_speed",opcua_real) winder_done is stream("winder_done",opcua_bool) winder_circum is local_stream("winder_circum",real) tempAlert is stream("tempAlert",bool) rfid_scan is stream("rfid_scan",rfid_type) rfid_stream is local_stream("rfid_stream",rfid_type) winder_output_data is stream("winder_output_data", winder_data_type) winder_roll_width is stream("winder_roll_width", opcua_real) winder_tension is stream("winder_tension", opcua_real) winder_line_speed is local_stream("winder_line_speed",real) winder_done_flag is local_stream("winder_done_flag", bool) winderTemp is local_stream("winderTemp",real) tensionTemp is local_stream("tensionTemp",real)
# Code_and_Logic circumference is fn p1:real -> p1*3.14 winder_circum = circumference(items.value) select items from winder_diameter
t1 is timer("t1") startup { arm t1 every 5(s) }
tempAlert = (true if (latest winder_temperature).value > 45 else false) select tick from t1 winder_line_speed = (speed.value*circum) select speed from winder_speed with circum from winder_circum rfid_stream = data select data from rfid_scan when data.readerName == station_id window_pattern is (item1:opcua_bool, peek, item2:opcua_bool -> item1.value == false and item2.value == true) winder_done_flag = event select event from (window_pattern from winder_done) when event == true
collector_pattern is (data:real .. { >= 1 } -> data) serial_id_collector is (data:rfid_type .. { >= 1 } -> data)
tensionTemp = item.value select item from winder_tension winderTemp = item.value select item from winder_temperature
winder_output_data = { process is winder_equip_str, line is line_num, aspect_ratio is ((latest winder_diameter).value / (latest winder_roll_width).value), avg_line_speed is avg(als), tension is (latest tensionTemp), avg_temp is avg(temp_list), serials is serial_list } select winddone from winder_done_flag with als from (collector_pattern from winder_line_speed) with temp_list from (collector_pattern from winderTemp) with serial_list from (serial_id_collector from rfid_stream)
winderSpeed is local_stream("winderSpeed",real) winderSpeed = item.value select item from winder_speed
winderDiameter is local_stream("winderDiameter",real) winderDiameter = item.value select item from winder_diameter
winder_machine_learning_data is stream("winder_machine_learning_data",{avg_temp is real,diameter is real, tension is real,speed is real})
winder_machine_learning_data = { avg_temp is avg(temp_list),diameter is (latest winderDiameter),tension is (latest tensionTemp),speed is avg(speed_list) } select winddone from winder_done_flag with temp_list from (collector_pattern from winderTemp) with speed_list from (collector_pattern from winderSpeed)

topic.title: Configure EdgeML

body.p: To configure EdgeML, open the EdgeML application from the FogHorn Manager.
We use the "Logistic Regression" machine learning model to identify if the winder machine is working correctly. We first need to train the model using existing winder data.

ul.li: Click New on the home page.
Enter Failure Prediction as the name and select Training New Model.
Select Logistic Regression.
Upload Train_Winder.csv, available in the user guide folder.
Select /analytics/winder_machine_learning_data in the topics dropdown and bind the fields to the model schema by clicking the checkboxes.
Select the data to publish with topic name FailurePrediction.
Review the information and click Finish.
Click the play icon to train the model. The status changes to Running.
